clean_story:
Forgetting on purpose. Rewiring old habits.


"Unlearning" means actively undoing what you’ve already learned—like erasing a sketch to redraw it better.


Your brain treats familiar habits like well-worn paths.
Unlearning is bulldozing that path to build a new one.


Example: A pianist trained to play with stiff fingers must unlearn tension to master fluid strokes.
Or a driver switching from manual to automatic—clutching becomes a ghost reflex.


Neuroscience calls this synaptic pruning: weak connections fade while stronger, useful ones strengthen.
It’s slower than learning because your brain resists change—like a river carving a new course.


Studies show it takes 3x longer to unlearn a skill than to learn it fresh.


The payoff?
Adaptability.
Breaking old loops to upgrade—like deleting an outdated app to free up space.


Neuroplasticity.
Cognitive dissonance.
The art of letting go.
